Description: Lower body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly an amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of hound attacking hare, to right (only jaws of hound remain, gripping hare's rump; top of hare's head and hind legs lost; added red on neck); swan or goose, to right (red on wing); below, red band between two dilute bands; below, part of a ray.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 453, no. B758)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0046) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 91, pl. I, no. 17)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
